sub_topic: Determining the conductivity of inorganic compounds
message_1: What is the conductivity of a 0.1 M solution of KCl at 25°C and how does it compare to the conductivity of a 0.1 M solution of glucose at the same temperature?
message_2:
To determine the conductivity of a 0.1 M solution of KCl at 25°C, we can use the equation:

Conductivity (κ) = Concentration (C) × Molar conductivity (Λm)

Molar conductivity (Λm) is the conductivity of a 1 M solution of an electrolyte. For KCl, the molar conductivity at 25°C is approximately 149.9 S cm²/mol. 

Now, we can calculate the conductivity of a 0.1 M KCl solution:

κ(KCl) = 0.1 M × 149.9 S cm²/mol = 14.99 S/m

As for the 0.1 M solution of glucose, glucose is a non-electrolyte, meaning it does not dissociate into ions when dissolved in water. Therefore, its conductivity will be significantly lower than that of an electrolyte like KCl. In fact, the conductivity of a glucose solution will be close to that of pure water, which is around 0.055 S/m at 25°C.

Comparing the conductivities:

κ(KCl) = 14.99 S/m
κ(glucose) ≈ 0.055 S/m

The conductivity of a 0.1 M KCl solution is significantly higher than that of a 0.1 M glucose solution at 25°C.
